Attachment and sense of presence in a virtual environment
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 22 May 2009

Attachment and sense of presence in a virtual environment

  • Helene S. Wallach1,
  • Marilyn P. Safir1 &
  • Idan Almog1 

Virtual Reality volume 13, pages205–217(2009)Cite this article

  • 271 Accesses

  • 3 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

This study is the first to investigate the connection between attachment categories and presence in Virtual Reality (VR) environments. Participants (99) completed an attachment questionnaire, experienced Virtual Reality Exposure (VRE) in a virtual airplane, and completed a presence questionnaire. Twenty-seven participants neglected to look at the virtual window, and reported lower levels of presence. A significant negative correlation between presence and avoidance was found. The correlation between presence and anxiety was not significant. Ethnicity (Jewish/non-Jewish) was found to be an intervening variable. A significant difference between levels of presence of attachment categories was found for participants who viewed the window: those in the Safe category reported the highest levels of presence, followed by the Anxious-Ambivalent group, the Dismissive-Avoidant group, and finally the Fearful-Avoidant group. Our results suggest there is a connection between one’s avoidance level and his/her attachment type and ability to experience the VRE as real and vivid.

Introduction

Although the use of Virtual Reality (VR) in therapy for anxiety disorders has increased in recent years, we know very little about the types of individuals who may benefit from VR exposure (VRE) (Rothbaum et al. 2006). “Presence” is the subjective experience that the client/subject feels as if s/he is “in” the situation even though it is not real. The experience of presence is necessary to ensure effectiveness of VRE. Although presence is influenced by both personality and technological factors (Steuer 1992), most studies have focused only on understanding the technological factors affecting presence. Few have explored personality factors (Laarni et al. 2004; Murray et al. 2007; Nicovich et al. 2005; Sas and O’Hare 2003). Thus, the present study was designed to investigate the connection between a person’s attachment type and his/her ability to experience presence in the VRE.

Attachment

Attachment theory focuses on the infant’s connection with its primary caregivers (Bowlby 1969). According to Bowlby, attachment is genetic, and occurs to preserve closeness of the caregiver in time of need. Attachment evolved because it enhances the likelihood for survival. Caregivers serve as “attachment figures” and are significant for both development of security in the world and the individual’s development. The infant develops an attachment type based on interactions with attachment figures. Although this system is most critical during the earliest stages of life, Bowlby (1988) assumed that this system remains active throughout the entire life span, and is represented by thoughts and behaviors that relate to maintaining an appropriate distance to the attachment figure. Bowlby (1973) assumed that attachment categories influence the creation of active models, including cognitive, behavioral, and emotional representations, which influence the way the world is perceived and analyzed.

Ainsworth et al. (1971) studied infants and found that attachment types can be divided into three categories: secure, anxious, and avoidant. The secure infant reacts to the world as a safe place, is curious and explorative in his/her environment, and is confident of his/her ability to deal with stressors. The anxious ambivalent infant expresses ambivalence toward his/her mother and views her/himself as helpless to deal with stressors on his/her own. Finally, the avoidant infant repels her/his mother’s closeness and views her/himself as lonely and as responsible for dealing with stressors on his/her own (Ainsworth et al. 1971).

Research on attachment began with children, but gradually expanded to examine attachment types in adults. Two parallel lines of research emerged (Simpson and Rholes 1998). The first line was pursued by developmental psychologists who focused on attachment in the nuclear family (child–parents), employing observations and interviews (AAI––adult attachment interview). The second one was developed by social psychologists, primarily dealing with research on close relationships with current spouses, employing self-report measures (questionnaires) (Bartholomew and Shaver 1998). The current study is based on social theories of attachment and employs self-report measures.

Hazan and Shaver found congruence between early patterns of attachment in childhood and those in adulthood (Hazan and Shaver 1987). Bartholomew and Horowitz (1991) found these patterns to be stable. Hazan and Shaver (1987) developed a questionnaire which classified adult participants into three attachment patterns, according to their feelings and behavior in a romantic relationship. A person with secure attachment makes close connections easily, feels comfortable with mutual dependence, and does not worry much about being abandoned or becoming close emotionally. A person with anxious ambivalent attachment is described as one who wants absolute connections with others. This results in rejection and difficulties in approaching others, enhancing fear of abandonment and disapproval of others. An avoidant attachment individual does not feel comfortable becoming emotionally close to others, has trouble trusting and depending on others, and feels stressed when others get close. The distribution of the three attachment types in adulthood was found to be similar to that found in infants. Thus, 56% of participants reported secure attachment, 24% reported avoidant attachment, and 20% reported anxious ambivalent attachment (Mickelson et al. 1997).

Over time, it became obvious that the three different attachment classification categories (safe, anxious, avoidant) only partially described the variety and complexity of the attachment schemas and therefore it appeared most appropriate to view attachment as a continuous dimension (Bartholomew and Horowitz 1991). Factor analysis of 60 different self-report measures produced two meta-dimensions which explained individual differences in attachment: an anxiety dimension and an avoidant dimension (Brennan et al. 1998).

The anxiety dimension reflects the degree of fear of being left without care and support of others while experiencing distress or anxiety. The avoidant dimension reflects the degree of lack of trust and emotional distance in interpersonal connections. Thus, “secure” attachment is one in which both anxiety and avoidance are low, while “anxious” attachment refers to high anxiety and low avoidance (preoccupied) and avoidant attachment (also labeled dismissing avoidant) refers to high avoidance and low anxiety. An additional attachment pattern was reported by Bartholomew and Horowitz (1991)––“fearful avoidant”––high in both avoidance and anxiety.

The division of attachment patterns into four distinct categories came under attack because clear boundaries between the categories are lacking (see for example Baldwin and Fehr 1995; Fraley and Waller 1998). Therefore, researchers have preferred to employ only two dimensions (anxiety and avoidance). This study examined both the four categories and two dimensions.

Personal differences in attachment influence the willingness to explore information about unknown things and to explore the environment (Bowlby 1973). Attachment figures provide an individual with a “secure base” from which he/she may go out and explore the world, show interest in its phenomena, and develop his/her abilities, remaining aware that in times of need he/she will be able to return to his/her attachment figure (Ainsworth 1973; Bowlby 1969, 1973, 1982).

Thus, those with secure attachment show balance between exploration and closeness. They may move from the attachment figure without being anxious or concerned about availability in time of need, and will return to it when danger occurs. Insecure infants show difficulty searching for information because they have serious doubts about the availability of their attachment figure, and are unsure whether a “secure base” will be available when exploration becomes dangerous.

Likewise, Mikulincer (1997) found that secure attachment is related to a variety of regulation strategies. Secure people trust their ability to regulate distress more than insecure people, and thus allow themselves to be exposed to new and sometimes threatening information. In contrast, insecure people may overestimate the threatening potential involved in exploration of the environment and develop serious doubts about their ability to handle such threats (Mikulincer 1998). In addition, people with secure attachment demonstrated higher levels of cognitive openness than those with insecure attachment, and were willing to retest faulty knowledge when new information came their way. Thus, attachment category correlates with curiosity (Mikulincer 1997).

Reaction to fearful stimuli is especially important in research on anxiety disorders. Based on the infant’s experiences with his/her caregivers, attachment type contributes to the development of mental models and representations (Bowlby 1973). Physical or psychological threats (such as the appearance of a predator, desertion by the attachment figure) automatically activate the attachment system, in order to preserve closeness of the protective figure (Ainsworth et al. 1978; Bowlby 1982; Cummings 1980; Wegner and Smart 1997). This phenomenon was found in adults, in addition to infants (e.g., Mikulincer and Florian 2000).

Adults with a history of secure attachment have found that maintaining closeness to their attachment figures helps to protect, comfort, and relieve stress in many situations. Thus, they are more likely to approach others when threatened or when experiencing distress (Bowlby 1982; Fraley and Shaver 1998; Simpson et al. 1992). Furthermore, Bowlby (1973) assumed that when facing threatening events secure people hold more positive and optimistic beliefs than insecurely attached individuals, (Berant et al. 2001). At stressful times secure individuals rely more on their partners than insecure individuals (Birnbaum et al. 1997). Thus, secure individuals’ attachment style works efficiently. The system is activated when threats occur and not in neutral contexts (Mikulincer et al. 2000), and activation arouses positive and calming associations (Mikulincer and Florian 1998, 2001).

The major goal in activating the attachment system when stress is experienced is to create a calming and balancing effect. However, for individuals who have an insecure attachment style, the attachment figure’s quality and quantity do not provide a “secure base.” Thus, even though the system is activated, it does not provide a calming effect (Mikulincer et al. 2002).

According to Mikulincer et al. (2002), anxious individuals experience hyper activation––they access their attachment figures in both threatening and non-threatening contexts. This hyper activation results in chronic activation of the attachment system and a “fight” response (Cassidy and Kobak 1988). Since attachment is insecure, hyper activation results in thoughts of rejection and separation, leading to a chronic experience of distress, which increases further in stressful times (Mikulincer and Florian 1998). In addition, hyper activation leads to overalertness, rumination about connections with the attachment figure, arousal of negative thoughts and emotions, incapacity to disengage from psychological pain and recurrent trials to enhance proximity to the attachment figure with attempts to enhance love and support by clinging and controlling responses (Cassidy and Kobak 1988). Thus, in times of stress, people who score high on anxiety tend to focus on their own distress and on negative thoughts, such that the attachment figure will not be available. This further enhances distress, leading to overestimation of the threat’s severity (Cassidy and Kobak 1988).

Unlike secure individuals, people who score high on avoidance remove themselves from the stressor cognitively or physically (Birnbaum et al. 1997). They experience deactivation of the attachment system, manifested by attempts to maximize distance from the attachment figure in order to avoid overdependency, to enhance self-reliance and control, and to suppress negative thoughts and emotions (Shaver and Mikulincer 2002). Therefore, avoidant and secure individuals exhibit similar external behavior. However, in contrast to secure individuals, avoidant individuals’ attachment systems are activated in response to stressors that directly engage the attachment system (e.g., divorce, diagnosis of a family member’s heart disease) as well as stressors that are not directly related (e.g., a missile attack on Israel during the Gulf war, army training, Mikulincer et al. 1990). Moreover, it was found that even though insecure individuals report adequate levels of well-being and appropriate adjustment in everyday life, in times of distress and ongoing pressure, they exhibit higher levels of distress and dysfunction and tend to avoid the stimulus more than secure individuals (Mikulincer and Florian 1998). In these situations, the cognitive system overloads and thoughts regarding the attachment figure increase, until a similar level of distress as that found in anxious people develops, and deactivation strategies are manipulated. However, when awareness of the threat cannot be suppressed, these deactivation strategies are insufficient and the individual is flooded with negative thoughts and emotions, making it more difficult for him/her to perform efficiently (Shaver and Mikulincer 2002). Shaver and Mikulincer (2002) assumed that under serious stressful conditions there is a difference between dismissing avoidant individuals (high avoidance and low anxiety) and fearful avoidant individuals (high levels on both anxiety and avoidance). For example, for dismissing avoidant individuals, deactivation and suppression strategies remain efficient, but under these conditions fearful avoidant individuals’ defense mechanisms collapse, because they must simultaneously approach and distance themselves from attachment figures, since they are unable to rely on them. This results in continuous activation of the attachment system (Shaver and Mikulincer 2002).

In summary, when a person is under stress, a process of seeking psychological or physical proximity to attachment figures or to their representations is initiated. While activation has a comforting and balancing effect for secure individuals, levels of anxiety remain high for insecure individuals (Mikulincer et al. 2002).

Attachment and presence

As previously mentioned, although employment of Virtual Reality in therapy for anxiety disorders has increased in recent years, we know very little about the types of individuals who may benefit from VR exposure (VRE) (Rothbaum et al. 2006). Thus, the present study was designed to explore the connection between a person’s attachment type and his/her ability to experience presence in the VRE. The connection between attachment and presence has not been previously investigated. We assumed that there would be a difference between secure and insecure individuals’ (anxious-ambivalent, avoidant-dismissive, avoidant-fearful) experiences of presence.

Individuals with a secure attachment style show balance between exploration and closeness. They may move from the attachment figure without being anxious or concerned about availability in time of need. They trust their ability to regulate distress and thus permit themselves to be exposed to new and sometimes threatening information. Therefore, they feel free to explore and engage in a novel situation, thus experiencing heightened presence in a VRE. In contrast, insecure attachment will lead to an overestimation of the threatening potential involved in exploration of the environment, to serious doubts about their ability to handle such threats, and to serious doubts about the availability of their secure base when exploration becomes threatening, resulting in difficulty in exploring the environment. Thus, insecure individuals will not feel free to explore and engage in a novel situation, experiencing lower presence in a VRE.

As previously mentioned, attachment may be seen as running along two continuous dimensions: anxiety and avoidance. The anxiety dimension reflects the degree of fear of being left without care and support of others while experiencing distress or anxiety. The avoidant dimension reflects the degree of lack of trust and emotional distance in interpersonal connections. Insecure attachment may result from high avoidance levels, high anxiety levels, or both. In times of stress, those high on avoidance remove themselves from the stressor cognitively or physically while those high on anxiety experience arousal of negative thoughts and emotions, and a heightened focus on their own distress. Those high on both avoidance and anxiety will experience more difficulties as they both approach and distance themselves. Therefore, we anticipate that securely attached individuals will experience the highest levels of presence and that anxious-ambivalent individuals will experience lower levels of presence than securely attached individuals due to the arousal of negative thoughts and emotions. Anxiety, unlike avoidance, may increase presence by increasing alertness to the surroundings. Thatcher et al. (2005) found that anxious people report high levels of immersion. In addition, dismissing-avoidant individuals tend to remove themselves cognitively from new situations. Therefore, we anticipate that dismissing-avoidant individuals will experience lower levels of presence than anxious-ambivalent individuals. Finally, we expect that fearful-avoidant individuals will experience the lowest levels of presence due to the fact that they employ the poorest coping strategies.

This investigation is the first step in investigating the connection between attachment and presence, thus enabling us to identify clients who may benefit from VR therapy. Our hypotheses are:

  1. 1.

    There will be a significant negative correlation between levels of avoidance and anxiety and presence, such that as self-reported levels of avoidance and anxiety increase, self-reported presence decreases.

  2. 2.

    There will be a difference in the levels of self-reported presence scores between secure individuals and insecure individuals, resulting in the highest presence scores for secure individuals, followed by anxious-ambivalent, then by avoidant-dismissive, and finally the lowest presence scores will be reported by avoidant-fearful individuals.

Method

Participants

Introductory psychology students (70 female, 29 male) received credit for participating in this study. The age of the participants ranged from 18 to 30 years, with a mean of 21 years. The majority (67%) of the participants were Jewish. Thus our participants were primarily young Jewish females (Table 1). Exclusion criterion was fear of flying. However, none of the participants reported flight phobia.

Materials and measures

The virtual reality environment

The environment, developed by Virtually Better, depicted the passenger compartment of a plane (Fig. 1). By moving one’s head to the left, changing scenery through the passenger’s window was revealed (Fig. 2). Participants wore a helmet manufactured by Emagin (model 3DVisor Z800), to which an external headphone was connected. Participants sat on a passenger seat donated by Arkia Airlines. The seat was connected to a speaker system (woofers) which caused it to vibrate when appropriate.

Demographics questionnaire

This questionnaire included three questions: gender, age, and ethnicity (Jew, Non-Jewish).

Presence

Presence was measured by the Presence Questionnaire (PQ) developed by Witmer and Singer (1998), containing 19 items, assessing the degree the subject felt he/she was “inside” the VRE. Subjects ranked presence on 7-point scales (1 low to 7 high). PQ has high reliability (α = 0.88) (Witmer and Singer 1998). The Hebrew version has high reliability as well (α = 0.89, Kizony 2006). PQ validity was assessed by examining correlations with simulator sickness during VRE (r = −0.43), and immersive tendencies (r = 0.24) (Witmer and Singer 1998).

Factor analysis revealed three factors (Witmer and Singer 1998): (1) Involvement/Control (IC, 11 items) refers to the degree of subjective control felt in the VRE, responsiveness of the environment to actions initiated in it, and involvement in VRE. (2) Natural (three items) refers to the degree the interactions with the environment felt natural. (3) Interface Quality (IQ, three items) refers to the degree of distraction caused by the quality of the interface.

Attachment

Experiences in Close Relationships (ECR) (Brennan et al. 1998). ECR contains two scales of 18 items each, measuring avoidance and anxiety. Participants rate agreement on Likert-type items ranging from 1 (highly disapprove) to 7 (highly approve). Ten items were reverse-scored. ECR is reliable (avoidance: 0.94; anxiety: 0.91) and has high content validity: Avoidance correlates highly with scales measuring avoidance and discomfort with closeness (r = 0.9, P < 0.001 with Carver’s Avoidance scale, 1994; r = 0.86, P < 0.001 with Carnelley et al. 1994, scales for discomfort with closeness). Anxiety correlates highly with scales measuring anxiety and preoccupation with attachment, jealousy, and fear of rejection (r = 0.88, P < 0.001 with Feeney et al. 1994, preoccupation scale; r = 0.82, P < 0.001 with Brennan and Shaver’s 1995, jealousy/fear of abandonment scale). Correlation between avoidance and anxiety is not significant, r = 0.11, n.s. (Brennan et al. 1998). The translated version is reliable (0.72 and 0.70, respectively, Mikulincer and Florian 2000).

Following Bartholomew and Shaver (1998) we calculated the four attachment styles according to the following equations:

$$ \begin{aligned} {\text{SECURE:}} & {\text{avoidance}}*3.2893296 + {\text{anxiety}}*5.4725318 - 11.5307833 \\ {\text{PREOCCUPIED:}} & {\text{avoidance}}*3.9246754 + {\text{anxiety}}*9.7102446 - 28.4573220 \\ {\text{FEARFUL}}: & {\text{avoidance}}*7.2371075 + {\text{anxiety}}*8.1776446 - 32.3553266 \\ {\text{DISMISSING}}: & {\text{avoidance}}*7.3654621 + {\text{anxiety}}*4.9392039 - 22.2281088 \\ \end{aligned} $$

Thus, participants received four scores, one on each attachment category, and classification was based on the highest score received.

Head movement

We noticed that some of our subjects neglected to move their heads (in spite of being informed that they will be able to do so when the helmet was placed on their heads.) These behaviors were noted and recorded. Head movement was scored negatively as no movement if the subject did not look at all at the virtual window, and positively as movement if he/she looked for any length of time at the virtual window. The data were analyzed post hoc.

Procedure

Participants were recruited through a notice posted on the Psychology Department’s online billboard. Participants filled out the demographic and attachment questionnaires, and were exposed to a brief (10 min) experience in a VR environment, which simulated flying in a plane. The plane took off, flew in nice weather, flew in stormy weather, and then landed. Afterward, the participants filled out the presence questionnaire. Prior to immersion the subjects were told that they will sit on an airplane seat wearing a head mounted display in which they will see and hear a 10-min virtual flight, that they can move their head to see the airplane, and to look at the airplane window at the surroundings.

Results

Presence and attachment variables

Natural (12.43) and IQ (14.73) mean scores (Table 2) were similar to the means reported by Witmer and Singer (1998) (12.36 and 14.65, respectively). IC subscale mean (49.03) was significantly lower than the mean reported by Witmer and Singer (1998) (57.39), t (98)  = −8.17, P < 0.001 (Table 2). In our study, participants were limited in the amount of control they had to change the VRE, in contrast with Witmer and Singer who requested their participants to actively interact in the VRE.

ECR’s two dimensions had high internal consistency (avoidance α = 0.87; anxiety α = 0.89), which was similar to those reported by Brennan and her associates (avoidance α = 0.94; anxiety α = 0.91). Pearson correlation between anxiety and avoidance was not significant, r = 0.19, n.s. Our participants’ scores were similar to those reported by Brennan (avoidance M = 2.93, SD = 1.15; anxiety X = 3.46, SD = 1.10) (Brennan, personal communication, January 20, 2009).

Level of presence as a function of looking at the window

Many participants (27 out of 99, 37%) failed to look at the virtual airplane window. Participants who looked at the window reported significantly higher levels of presence on the IC scale t (97) = 4.66; P < 0.001 as well as on the Natural scale t (97) = 2.37; P < 0.05 compared to those who did not look at the window. There was no significant difference between these two groups on the IQ scale, t (97) = 0.44; n.s. (Table 2). Therefore looking at the window was determined to be an intervening variable.

Factors affecting window viewing

Most of the Jewish participants (54 out of 66, 82%) looked at the window in contrast with non-Jewish participants who were divided evenly between viewers and non-viewers. In addition, a higher percentage of men looked at the window (27 out of 29, 93%) than women (45 out of 70, 62%) (Table 3).

A significant association between ethnicity, gender, and window viewing was found χ(3) = 17.49, P < 0.01. Significantly more non-Jewish women failed to look at the virtual window than any other group.

A significant association between age and window viewing was found as well t (97) = 2.95; P < 0.005. Participants who looked at the window were significantly older than participants who did not look at the window. This probably occurred as a result of the Jewish participants (most of whom looked at the window) being significantly older than the non-Jewish participants, t (97) = 13.39, P < 0.005.

There were no differences between the two groups on avoidance and anxiety levels, t (97) = 0.46, n.s.

Presence as a function of demographic variables

No differences were found between men and women on level of presence: IC: t (97) = 0.11, n.s; Natural: t (97) = −0.6, n.s.; IQ: t (97) = −0.15, n.s. No difference was found between Jewish participants and non-Jewish participants on level of presence: IC: t (97) = 0.56, n.s; Natural: t (97) = −1.02, n.s.; IQ: t (97) = 1.57, n.s. Finally, correlations between age and presence were not significant: IC: r = −0.003, n.s; Natural: r = −0.144, n.s.; IQ: r = 0.76, n.s. (Table 2). Thus, no differences were found in the level of presence as a function of age, gender, or ethnicity.

Avoidance and anxiety as a function of demographic variables

Jewish participants had significantly lower levels of avoidance than non-Jewish participants, t (97) = −3.08, P < 0.05. No differences were found between the two groups on the anxiety dimension t (97) = −0.041, n.s. (Table 4). This is in accordance with previous studies which found higher levels of avoidance among Arabs in Israel in comparison with the Jewish population (Pines 2004).

There was a significant negative correlation between age and avoidance r = −0.21, P < 0.05. The correlation between age and anxiety was not significant, r = −0.12, n.s.

No differences were found between men and women on level of attachment (avoidance, t (97) = 0.11, n.s.; anxiety, t (97) = 0.37, n.s.).

Thus, Jewish participants had lower scores on avoidance than non-Jewish participants, and the older the participants were, the less was avoidance reported. The non-Jewish participants were significantly younger than the Jewish participants t (97) = 13.39, P < 0.005 (Table 1). A multiple regression was conducted with avoidance as the dependent variable, and both age and ethnicity as independent variables. A significant correlation was found between ethnicity and avoidance (β = 0.31, P < 0.05), whereas the correlation between age and avoidance was not significant (β = 0.01, n.s.). Therefore it was decided to treat ethnicity, and not age, as an intervening variable.

Attachment and presence

Our first hypothesis was that negative correlations would be found between both avoidance and anxiety and level of presence. We conducted a Pearson correlation between avoidance and anxiety and each of the three presence ratings (IC, Natural, IQ) in the general sample and also separately for the groups of window viewers and non-viewers, and separately for the Jewish and non-Jewish participants (Table 4). This hypothesis was partly confirmed. In the general sample, there was a significant, negative correlation between level of avoidance and IC, r = −0.24, P < 0.05. No other correlations were significant in the general sample. Examining the subgroups formed by ethnicity and window viewing, the only significant correlations were: between avoidance and IC among Jewish participants who looked at the window, r = −0.33, P < 0.05, and between avoidance and IC in non-Jewish participants who did not look at the window r = −0.55, P < 0.05.

Our second hypothesis was that there would be a difference between the four attachment categories in level of presence: secure subjects would score the highest, anxious-ambivalent second, dismissive-avoidant third, and fearful-avoidant would receive the lowest presence scores. This hypothesis was confirmed in two groups: window viewers and IC scale (χ2(3) = 8.9, P < 0.05) and Jewish window viewers group with IC scale (χ 2(3)  = 7.78, P = 0.051) (Table 5).

Discussion

The major goal of this study was to evaluate the correlation between a person’s attachment category and his/her feeling of presence in the virtual environment, in order to expand the current knowledge about the optimal VR user profile.

Window viewing and presence

A large percentage of our participants did not turn their heads to view the virtual window, thus limiting their experience in the VRE. Window viewers also scored higher on presence; therefore, we decided to analyze the results of viewers and non-viewers separately.

These differences between the groups seem reasonable when taking into consideration factors affecting presence: interactivity and vividness. Interactivity is the degree the technological system allows the user to affect the content or shape of the VRE, while vividness is the technological system’s ability to produce environments which are sensually rich (Coyle and Thorson 2001; Naimark 1990; Schubert et al. 2001; Steuer 1992). Thus differences on IC scores between viewers and non-viewers may reflect the level of interactivity with the VRE, while differences between these Natural scores may reflect the level of vividness experienced.

Vividness has two elements: sensorial breadth and sensorial depth of the stimuli (Held and Durlach 1992). Sensorial breadth was held constant in the current study; therefore, most of the variance between viewers and non-viewers resulted from sensorial depth. Wirth et al. (2007) claimed that a continuous flow of exact sensual information helps preserve the user’s attention to the VRE more effectively than a partial or fragmented flow. Since only those who looked at the virtual window experienced such a flow, it may be assumed that among viewers, the high level of sensorial depth helped preserve attention and interest in the VRE.

The capacity to be actively involved in the VRE makes it unique and different from other perceptual environments (Casati and Pasquinelli 2005a, b). The greater the level of involvement, the greater the experience of presence and as a result the level of involvement increases (Casati and Pasquinelli 2005a, b). Perhaps this accounts for the higher levels of presence among participants who “explored” the VR environment and “discovered” the window. On the other hand, those who did not “explore” the environment, and thus did not “discover” the window, may have experienced lower vividness (all they saw was a static image of the seat in front of them), and thus, their motivation to be involved may have been diminished.

Presence increases if participants can prepare for and expect the upcoming changes, even if they are unable to control them (Held and Durlach 1992). Only by looking at the window could one experience the plane’s flight. This may explain higher presence among window viewers. These explanations serve to explain why window avoiders experienced lower levels of presence. However, it is unclear why they avoided looking at the window in the first place.

Avoiding the virtual window may be attributed to low levels of motivation at commencement of participation which may then decrease levels of attention to the surroundings, and thus lower presence (Thatcher et al. 2005; Wirth et al. 2007). Therefore, window avoiders may have lacked interest in participating or perhaps, did not experience the environment as “real” and this reduced their motivation. An alternative explanation, which we hypothesize is more relevant to understanding this phenomenon, may be attributed to gender and ethnicity. Non-viewers were primarily non-Jewish women. The experiment was conducted in a closed room with a male researcher who helped the participants position the HMD, entailing minimal physical contact. Moreover, at the beginning of the VRE, the light was dimmed and remained so until the VRE was completed. Perhaps this caused some of our female participants to feel uncomfortable and interfered with their participation. This is particularly true for non-Jewish females. In recent years, there has been a significant reduction in the limitations placed on Arab women to study and work outside their homes. However, minimal interaction with men is still considered desirable (Keddie 1990; Semyonov et al. 1999). Therefore, we hypothesize that our experimental situation created personal discomfort for some participants. However, this hypothesis must be tested. We must also determine whether Jewish women who did not explore the VR environment also come from more traditional backgrounds.

Presence and attachment

Our first hypothesis that there will be a negative correlation between avoidance/anxiety and presence was partially confirmed. A negative correlation between avoidance level and the IC scale was found for the total sample, for Jewish participants who looked at the window and among non-Jewish participants who did not look at the window, revealing that participants felt control and involvement in the VR environment. However, no significant correlation was found between anxiety and presence.

Avoidance and presence

Witmer and Singer (1998) found that presence consists of three factors: 1. Amount of control and involvement in the VRE (IC). 2. Degree to which interactions with the environment are experienced as natural and consistent with reality (Natural). 3. Quality of technological interface (IQ). IC was found to be the most important factor. When an individual feels that s/he has a high level of control over or interaction with the VRE his/her feeling of presence is enhanced (Witmer and Singer 1998). We found a significant negative correlation between avoidance and the IC scale. Thus, the higher the individual’s score on the avoidance dimension, the less control and involvement he/she feels in the VRE. Why does this occur? There are two possible explanations. The first assumes that avoidance influences involvement in the VRE. This is supported by findings regarding the correlation between avoidance and curiosity to search for new information (Mikulincer 1997). Avoiders show lower levels of exploration and tend to suppress curiosity to new stimuli or situations, thus reducing their involvement in the VRE, resulting in lower presence (Casati and Pasquinelli 2005).

An alternative explanation is that avoidance directly affects feelings of control in the VRE. This explanation relates to findings that, in contrast with individuals who score high on the anxiety dimension, individuals who score high on the avoidance scale distance themselves cognitively or behaviorally from the source of discomfort (Birnbaum et al. 1997). Since in this study participants were unable to distance themselves from the stimulus, it may be assumed that the new stimulus (the unfamiliar environment, the experience of flight, etc.) aroused feelings of discomfort and lack of control. Perhaps avoiders, unlike secure and anxious-ambivalent individuals, are less likely to relate to the researcher as an attachment object in order to reduce their anxiety because of their tendency toward self-reliance (Shaver and Mikulincer 2002). Since behavioral “flight” was not an option in the current study, the only way participants could deal with discomfort was by cognitive “flight,” which on the one hand distances them from the stimulus but on the other hand lowers their levels of involvement and presence in the VRE.

Anxiety and presence

When we examined the four attachment categories, we found a significant difference between them. If only the avoidant dimension was relevant, there would have been no difference between the anxious ambivalent and the secure groups or between the dismissive avoidant and the fearful avoidant groups. However, correlations between anxiety and presence were not significant. Perhaps our manipulation, the flight experience, was not relevant or intense enough for significant differences to be found on the anxiety dimension. Perhaps if the content of the VR environment had related to personal relationships, to separation, or to elements which are known to arouse attachment systems in anxious individuals (Cassidy and Kobak 1988), a correlation between anxiety and presence may have been produced.

Ethical considerations mandated excluding flight phobic participants. We hypothesize that to obtain significant differences on anxiety we would have to increase the strength of our manipulation or to sample participants who report some level of fear. Also, unlike avoiders, who do not seek personal contact while dealing with discomfort but try to rely on themselves (Shaver and Mikulincer 2002), anxious people tend to request help and even “cling” while distressed. Thus, it may be that the presence of the researcher in the room acted as a mediator for anxiety.

Presence and the four attachment categories

The second hypothesis that the level of presence will be influenced by attachment category was confirmed among Jewish participants and among window viewers. For these groups the four attachment groups differed on presence ratings as predicted on the IC scale: “secure” participants reported highest levels of presence, followed by “anxious-ambivalent”, then “dismissive-avoidant,” and finally “fearful-avoidant” reported the lowest levels of presence in the VRE. The lack of significant results among non-Jewish participants may have resulted from the small number of participants, or the high percentage of participants in this group that did not view the virtual window.

Suggestions for future studies

We found a correlation between avoidance and level of involvement and control in the VRE. It would be interesting to examine the correlation between avoidance-involvement and avoidance-control separately. It may be assumed that the avoidance-involvement correlation would be relevant with threatening and non-threatening stimulus, and the correlation between avoidant-control would be primarily relevant while facing threatening stimulus.

Since anxiety did not correlate significantly with presence, it would be interesting to examine this correlation using VR environments that include interpersonal interactions such as standing in front of an audience. It would also be interesting to examine whether the presence of the therapist is an important factor in a neutral VR environment such as flight. Does the correlation between anxiety and presence change when the therapist leaves the room? Is the level of presence lower in a session in which the therapist informs the patient that he/she is taking a vacation? These are questions to be examined in future research.

Although we found a significant difference on levels of presence between the four attachment categories, we were unable to determine the minimal level of presence that is required for a VRE to be effective. Thus, even though dismissive-avoidant and fearful-avoidant individuals reported low levels of presence, it may be possible that VRE therapy will still be effective for them.

Although self-report measures are generally relevant, sensitive, and convenient, they are also subject to response bias and thus have lower validity than objective measures. Difficulties with self-report measures abound. Participants may respond, for example, in a socially desirable fashion, and ethnic minorities may not fully understand the questions. Behavioral and physiological measures (e.g., startle response) are, however, objectively measurable. We suggest that it is important to examine differences between self-report measurements and objective tools for measuring presence. Therefore, we strongly suggest recording head and viewer’s eye movements as s/he explores the VRE. These behaviors should be evaluated as an objective measure, since we found that turning to view the virtual window correlated with presence. Slater (2004) states that presence cannot be measured solely via post-experience self-report questionnaires. We suggest that recording head and eye movement will prove to be an additional and reliable objective measure.

Practical implications

Our findings raise the possibility of determining likelihood of success of VR procedures, before commencing treatment. Additionally they enable us to estimate the chances of an individual feeling a high degree of presence in the VRE. Furthermore, they reveal the negative influence of avoidance and anxiety on presence and demonstrate that in an environment not related to personal connections (i.e., flight), avoidance has more impact on presence than anxiety.

Methodological problems

Our sample consisted of introductory psychology students who are required to participate in a number of research studies in order to obtain course credit. They were young (18–30) and in their first year of college and thus not a representative sample of the general population.

When analyzing our results it became clear that the average IC scores were lower than that reported by Witmer and Singer (1998). Their participants had different levels of involvement, which may have resulted in the differences between the findings.

Our participants’ ethnicity and gender were factors that we had not anticipated. We did not take into consideration the effect of being alone in a darkened room with a male researcher might have upon women and, in particular, non-Jewish women. Having a female researcher presenting the VR procedure may have produced different results.

Due to ethical considerations we excluded phobic participants. Phobic individuals experience greater sense of presence when close to phobic stimulus; therefore, it stands to reason that our results would be more significant employing this population. However, this hypothesis should only be tested in a situation that enables the participants to receive aid to overcome their anxieties/phobias.

Since we discovered that presence was influenced by viewing the virtual window, we recommend either that participants be shown the VR environment before they enter it or to verbally suggest that they move their heads to look around the VR environment. This may increase motivation as well as produce higher feelings of presence.

Summary

Presence is defined as the experience of “being there” even though physically located in a different reality. Nonetheless, there is no current agreement about what “being there” means or which variables engage this subjective feeling (Sacau et al. 2008; Steuer 1992). Although presence has become a primary concept in VR, the number of studies that investigated the impact of personal attributes on presence is relatively limited. The majority of researchers have primarily focused on the influence of technological elements (Sas and O’Hare 2003). Even those studies that examined personal attributes on presence have primarily investigated cognitive abilities and level of experience (Sacau et al. 2008).

The current study attempted to identify connections between two concepts that are embedded in different areas: attachment from the personality domain and presence which has became a primary concept in VR and related to the cognitive-behavioral domain. Our results demonstrate the importance of this examination. We believe that we have demonstrated the first and clear relationship between a person’s avoidant level and his/her ability to experience the VRE as vivid and rich. However, this is the first step and further research is necessary. We hope this study has contributed to the identification of the optimal VR user. We believe that we have also demonstrated that knowledge from dynamic fields of psychology may shed light on research in the cognitive field in general and specifically in virtual reality .
